text:
Problem Overview

In this Problem, students will use their definition of similar figures to decide which shape in a group is not similar and then create their own group of similar figures with an imposter.

Revision Comments

CMP STEM Problem Format

General Arc of Learning

Unit Arc of Learning

Mathematical Overview

Learning Aids

Teaching Aids

Family Letters

Assessments

ACE Homework

Emerging Mathematical Ideas

Continue using proportional relationships to determine scaled figures. Compare and measure geometric figures that are both similar and non-similar figures.

NWDYK

What are strategies for identifying if shapes have been scaled (similar figures) or if the shapes are imposters?

Launch (Getting Started)

Connecting to Prior Knowledge

Remind students of the work they did in Investigation 2 when they were finding the Wump imposters.

Suggested Questions:

  • How did we decide which Wumps were imposters? (Answer will vary. Students should be able to talk about scale factor, corresponding angle measures, ratios of adjacent sides, coordinate rules, etc.)
  • How could we use these ideas to find imposters with other shapes? (Answer will vary. Students should be able to talk about scale factor, corresponding angle measures, ratios of adjacent sides, coordinate rules, etc.)

Presenting the Challenge

Have students work with a partner on this Problem. In the Initial Challenge they will look at each set and determine which shape is the imposter. Have each partner group work on 2-3 sets.

Distribute Learning Aid 4.3: Sets of Figures.

Implementation Note: Have each partner group work on 2-3 of the sets in the Initial Challenge.
